info.game_comments: First round and first 16 clues of second round only.

(1, 1).clue: He helped pioneer the 40-hour work week by introducing it at his Michigan auto factories

(2, 1).clue: This Walt Whitman work began as a collection of 12 poems in 1855; by 1892 it contained hundreds

(3, 1).clue: This president's home, the Hermitage, is located on Rachel's Lane

(4, 1).clue: From the Old French for "crib", it's a representation of a Nativity scene

(5, 1).clue: Originally, the ell was a measurement from the fingertip to this

(1, 2).clue: He fired the first liquid fuel rocket; it went up about 40 feet

(2, 2).clue: This Scottish poet wrote an ode to "To a Mouse, on Turning Her Up in Her Nest with the Plough, November 1785"

(3, 2).clue: In 1873 Central University was renamed this for the "Commodore" who gave it a $1 million gift

(4, 2).clue: From Old English for "One that breaks faith", it's a male witch

(5, 2).clue: A candela is a measurement of the intensity of this

(1, 3).clue: A composite photo of this film star with Caruso in Heaven was circulated after he died on August 23

(2, 3).clue: This Scotsman's original title for "A Child's Garden of Verses" was "Penny Whistles"

(3, 3).clue: This singer's museum near Nashville has a section featuring the Carter family

(4, 3).clue: This term for a little angel often depicted as a rosy-cheeked child comes from Hebrew

(5, 3).clue: The boiling point of water at sea level is 212 on the Fahrenheit scale & this on the Celsius scale

(1, 4).clue: This "colorful" football star was paid $300,000 for his role in "One Minute to Play"

(2, 4).clue: Ludovico Ariosto wrote the romantic epic about this "furioso" paladin

(3, 4).clue: From 1943 to 1974, Ryman auditorium was the broadcast site of this radio program

(4, 4).clue: From Sanskrit meaning "Great Queen", it's the wife of a Majarajah

(5, 4).clue: Equivalent to 39.37 inches, its name comes from a Latin word meaning "measure"

(1, 5).clue: On November 1 this, company, the 1st radio network, was formed under Pres. David Sarnoff

(2, 5).clue: He said his title for "The Waste Land" was suggested by a book on the Grail legend

(3, 5).clue: Nashville's Parthenon has a 42-foot replica of this goddess

(4, 5).clue: Our word "bog" probably came from this language; it helps if you think of peat bogs

(5, 5).clue: The ancient Romans used this unit of weight, which they called a "libra"

(1, 1).clue: In the 5th C. BC Athens headed the Delian & this militaristic city, the Peloponnesian League

(3, 1).clue: In 1890 William Kemmler became the first person executed in this shocking manner

(4, 1).clue: The German title of this Franz Werfel novel is called Das Lied von Bernadette

(6, 1).clue: The myocardium muscle performs the main work of this organ

(1, 2).clue: When the Roman Empire split in two in 395 A.D., Greece remained in the half called this

(3, 2).clue: In 1964 he was convicted of misappropriating $1.7 million in Teamster pension funds

(6, 2).clue: The brain stem connects the cerebrum with this part of the nervous system

(1, 3).clue: Mathematician & philosopher who discovered the intervals in an octave & probably played a mean triangle

(3, 3).clue: Implicated in the Lincoln assassination, this doctor was sent to a prison in the Dry Tortugas

(6, 3).clue: A delicate membrane called the pleura covers each of these organs

(1, 4).clue: The possession of Amazon Queen Hippolyta that is captured by Hercules

(3, 4).clue: "Mad Bomber" George Metesky terrorized this city in the 1950s

(6, 4).clue: The hypothalamus controls this "master gland" which in turn controls others

(1, 5).clue: In the 4th century BC it was thought if this creature of Asklepios licked your eyes it might cure blindness

(3, 5).clue: This legendary highwayman was finally hanged as a horse thief at York in 1739

(6, 5).clue: This largest part of the large intestine includes sections called the transverse & decending
